nodes.text: An economic framework based on a quantum probabilistic propensity function (quantum propensity) provides a consistent, dynamic, and better-suited model of decision-making and financial transactions than classical utility-based equilibrium models
Quantum probability (2-norm, complex amplitudes) naturally models superposition, interference, and entanglement, which map to cognitive phenomena that violate classical probability and logic

Decision-makers can be described by a propensity function specifying the probability of transacting (instead of a utility function), and this propensity can be expressed in quantum terms as squared amplitudes of an underlying wave function

A quantum-circuit representation (qubits, unitary gates, C-NOT) can simulate sequences of contextual decisions and produce the same joint outcome probabilities as sequential projective measurements, making it a flexible method to model cognitive effects
A two-qubit circuit with rotation gates A and B plus a C-NOT reproduces order effects and can be adapted (by swapping control) to reverse question order, so it simulates context-dependent responses

Specific cognitive phenomena modeled: order effect (question order dependence), disjunction effect (contextual interference), preference reversal (context-dependent choice), and social entanglement (e.g., prisoner's dilemma behavior)

Interference arises in quantum circuits because negative and complex projections allow cancellation of components after unitary rotations (example: Hadamard transforms superposition to deterministic outcome)
A continuous propensity distribution (e.g., normal over log-price) corresponds to the squared amplitude of a wave function and can be interpreted as a quantum superposition over price outcomes

Appendix result: single-qubit sequential measurement representation using unitary matrices A and B is equivalent in final outcome probabilities to the two-qubit entangling circuit for arbitrary unitary A and B
From a given propensity function P(x) one can derive an entropic force F(x) = gamma * P'(x) / P(x) that describes the tendency of a mental state or market to move toward maximum entropy

Threshold effect for preference reversal: when subjective/contextual factors are random and comparable to objective factors, a switch from a more attractive to a less attractive option occurs only if cost ratio x2/x1 > 3; this criterion has empirical support

Mapping a normal propensity to a quantum harmonic oscillator: ground-state probability is normal with mean mu and sd sigma; associated quantum mass scales inversely with variance (m proportional to 1/sigma^2) and gamma scales with hbar and oscillator frequency

Implication for market dynamics: entropic force from joint buyer-seller propensities yields a spring-like linear restoring force near mid-price, enabling a dynamics-based description (forces, mass, frequency) of transactions and mean reversion

Energy/information required to change propensity (e.g., flip preference by factor ~3) is of order the base energy of a quantum oscillator (~ (hbar * omega)/2), linking cognitive switching to quantized energetic units

The quantum propensity framework can be applied to model financial statistics, pricing and volume of options, and strategic defaults by incorporating discrete quantum states and entanglement-induced correlations

Conclusion: Quantum economics reframes value from utility to propensity, incorporates cognitive interference and entanglement, provides consistent units (forces, mass, energy) for economic dynamics, and treats subjective and objective factors on equal footing while acknowledging social complexity
